reviewText:
Early Access Review

First, some pros and cons.

Pros:
- The gameplay is pretty solid and enjoyable.
- It's progressing quickly. Every week the game gets updated with significant improvements and features.
- The community is very friendly, so long as you don't act like a total dickweed.
- The marine characters feel sufficiently heavy and massive. There's a lot of momentum in your movement, and it feels good just to run around.

Cons:
- Bugs. There's a lot of little annoying issues that are still waiting to be smoothed over.
- Not much content. 3 maps, 2 factions. Certainly not worth $50 in itself.
- Performance is bad. Really bad. (Though there's supposed to be some major optimizations coming pretty soon).
- Some of the animations, sounds, and effects are lackluster. (But in all likelyhood, they're not anywhere near final).
- The melee system is a rock-paper-scissors game of chance – by design. It doesn't work well, feel right, or look good.

Right, now here's the skinny on the project's goals.

At launch there will be 4 playable factions: Orks, Eldar, Space Marines, and Chaos Space Marines. Tyranids with comprise the 5th faction, though they will be NPCs used in PvE content (there have been rumors of playable tyranids, and the developers have said it's something they're looking into). The plan for the meta is similar to that of Heroes & Generals – that being a persistent tactical map with outposts and fortresses connected to one another through a lattice. Each outpost/fortress with be its own instanced 'map'. Outposts will host smaller skirmishes, while fortresses will be massive siege battles of 100+ players.

There are plans to merge the facilities in sets of 3 outposts and 1 fortress further down the line (post-launch), each of these instances would be roughly 1/4 the size of a continent in Planetside 2. Battles in those areas would likely have 300-500 players. The end goal is to open the continent (which is much larger than any in Planetside 2)  completely,

By lauch there will also be terminators, drop pods, hero characters, elite units, social hubs, and more things I don't remember off the top of my head.

If that sounds interesting to you, I reccomend picking it up. Even if it's not worth the $50 right now, it's quickly shaping up to be. If you're on the fence, I say wait. Keep an eye on the progress and jump in when you think it's worth it.

Early Access Review

Initial Impressions: So far pretty fun! Definitely an early access title so expect the bare bones as far as maps and features, bugs & frame dips. With that said the core mechanics are solid in their current stage. A lot of roots in the thq space marine with a dash of battlefield/tf2. Maps are pretty basic at this point so if your not one for playing a game at an early stage I would hold off for a few months as right now there is only chaos and space marines to play.

If you have been looking for a good third person shooter set in the wh40k universe this may scratch that itch. Just be mindful of the system requirements. On  a titan I am not having any significant performance issues, but I would recommend a card less than 2 years old if you want to play now as optimization has a ways to go. This could be the wh40k you have been dreaming of though... only time will tell once they roll out the remaining two races & tyranid meta game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Runs nice and looks amazing for alpha/early access. Obviously, being early access, there are a few graphical glitches here and there, but for the most part it runs smoothly. Curently I am running everything on high with a GTX 760, and it's smooth. The game is fun, but there are a fair few issues with balance that really need to be addressed.

Melee is far too overpowered in this game atm. A single space marine equipped with sword and shield can walk on into a room full of chaos marines, and vice versa, and wipe them all out. The majority of matches I have played so far, the top places on the leaderboard have all been melee marines.

Mark of Nurgle on chaos marines is too good also. You can land headshot after headshot on marked marines, and they won't die. As such, most matches are won by Chaos.

There are issues with some weapons being too good to not use, and some being plain useless. The Lascannon for example, tickles if it hits you, whereas the plasma gun, charged up, can one shot a group of marines.

It can sometimes be difficult to tell the difference between a team mate and an enemy. The Space Marines and Chaos Space Marines do look different when you can stop and admire how good htey look, but in the thick of the fight, it can sometimes be very difficult to tell them apart. The game does add a small red marker above enemies, but I have found that this marker can sometimes vanish, or it's jsut too small to notice.

There are big issues with spawning in the game currently. It feels like everyone who died in a certain time period will spawn at once, in one big clump. Some players, based on the map, take advantage of this and will have a charged up plasma gun waiting for such an event.

Overall, the game is alot of fun and looks stunning. It feels like a Warhammer game should. Any fan of the Warhammer 40k universe will love playing this, if they can ignore the current issues that need addressing. But as it is an alpha/early access, these are to be expected. The game does have a rather steep learning curve, such as how hte melee combat works, but it is alot of fun once you start to understand things.

Currently as it is, I would recommend this game, but only to people who enjoy the Warhammer universe.

WH40k.
Its the whipping boy of all IPs.
Most of the games turn out to be bad or mediocre.

This game is in the latter category.

Good:
WH40k universe

Executions.
Vehicles.
Chainswords.
Sorcerors.
Emprah.
Community is kind of Quiet Mouse.

Cons:(much of this is due to early access)
Alpha.

Balance is currently back and forth.


TLDR:
WH40k fans buy it now;support your community!
non WH40k fans; i will see you eventually on the battlefield, and your souls will be forfeit to the chaos gods!

BTW: i dont ever recommend early access games! i recommend this one!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At this point in the game it is still under development but it seems to have issues running on Windows 10 at least from my pc specs and the system requirements wil change as the game progresses I am sure but I have a good PC set up capable of playing Taxing Pc games like Total War Atilla, World of Tanks, SWToR and Diablo III at max settings without issue.   The game is not recognized in NVIDIA EXPERIENCE software as of yet so forcing GRAHPICS settings takes a little know how but it's a good game... like I said realy choppy on windows 10.. Hopefully it will improve as it develops.    For being an early release ALPHA.. I would give this title a 7/10.

Cons- Lack of known patching and updating status. Lack of servers, options and general game settings  are extremely limited.

Pros- Really well done physics, combat, enviorment  and  art work. It's warhammer 40k 3rd person style and it's got a Gears of War feel to it. I can't wait to see the title grow as it will simply just get better if the developers invest a little bit more to get the ball really rolling.

I would encourage people to pick up this title and invest in what these guys are trying to accomplish in the hopes they fund it right and get it going. The player dedication is great and there are people pickiing up this title in groves it seems.

This is not some indie title. It's gonna be good if it gets some money flow going and put to good use.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all if you want to give this game a whirl and be knee deep in traitor scum or laughing maniacally while you blast and carve your way through loyalist lapdogs then jump on in and use this referal code:- EC-SPIF6U7G921Q2

As a long time fan of Warhammer from my early days playing the table top I can hand on heart say that this game shows great potential; if you were a fan of Space Marine then this game will be right up your street. The game is by no means perfect there are still a number of bugs and balancing issues to iron out but being early access thats expected and with each update the game continues to shine. Right now we dont have dedicated servers for EU but the game is not unplayable and I have not had many issues with ping/latency. I would advise that you do some research or watch a few streams just so you know what to expect before you decide on making a purchase to play early access. If you are still unsure I would say wait for the full games release if your not up for waiting for content updates with each new patch but now is the time to really get a glimpse of the community and forge your squads/guilds ready for the full experience.

The game may feel a little barebones as an arena shooter but it has a selection of great diverse maps available to do battle on while utilizing tanks, teamwork and tactics to bludgeon your foes and laugh at their inferiority. There is just something rewarding and satisfying about storming a fortified position under a hail of plasma and bolter rounds with the echoes of heavy support in the distance and the descent of chainsword wielding death chewing through any unfortunate victim who wandered into their path.

There is still plenty of things yet to come while the devs and players test the core combat mechanics and stress test the servers such as customisation, new factions and classes, PVE and a large scale world to conquer. The game is worthy of the support and I would ask everyone to check out the official site and research what the game is going to bring to the table.https://www.eternalcrusade.com/

In it's current state I would give this game a solid 7/10 taking into account:

. Bugs/errors such as rare disconnects or reloading bugs.
. Combat (A little rock/paper/scissors but there is a nack to it with light/charge/bash attacks.)
. The community; a diverse group of skilled players there is alot of banter and teamwork.
. Ping/latency (Not too bad considering but more servers will come its still Alpha).


So finally why do I recommend this game to you and why do I continue to rack up more and more hours of playtime..... well heres a few questions to you guys:-

. Want to worship the Chaos gods and bath in the blood of your enemies as you crush your foes to show your true devotion to the ruinous powers? Then get this game!

. Want to devote yourself to the emperor and slay the heretics? Then get this game!

. Want to wield devestating weaponry and unload it into the next poor soul who looks at you funny be it a plasma cannon, heavy bolter etc? Then get this game!

. Want to work as a team to overcome impossible odds in the heat of battle? Then get this game!

. Want to revel in your factions conquest of Arkhona? Then get this game!


(And while orks/eldar are not here yet they still deserve a mention)

. Want to unleash your inner WAAAAAAGGGGHHHHHHH? Then get this game!

. Want to banter as an ork over voice chat? Then get this game!

. Want to unleash the power of the Eldar and earn glory for the craftworld? Then get this game!

I recommend this game for anyone who:

- Enjoys the multiplayer combat of Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine
- Likes Planetside 2 and Warhammer
- Doesn't mind temporary FPS issues and bugs (such is the way of Alpha)

I had a LOT of fun with this Alpha.  The FPS was a thing, but mine was pretty average considering.  I am thankful for that.

There is a lot that needs addition, but again, such is the way of Alpha.  The game is functional and feedback is ALWAYS considered.  I have never seen a company more dedicated to a game and its community.  These guys and gals are honest, and this game is for more than a quick buck.  Lore is taken into account (though not to an extreme amount where it negatively affects gameplay) and nothing is really that unfriendly toward the lore.  It also helps that everything they do is approved by Games Workshop themselves.

So I'm going to list the postitives and negatives of this alpha thus far.  Now, I will not include things that aren't in the game as negatives, only what is currently there.  They have a lot of plans in terms of visual customization, weapons, races, vehicles, maps, terrain, so on and so forth.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As far as an early access game goes this is looking very promising. Weekly twitch shows give players a sneak peak at what's being worked on  as well as giving us the opportunity to interact with the games development.

Currently the game plays as a lobby shooter based on 16vs16 and 32vs32 matches of chaos vs space marines(the long term plan is to grow the size of maps and players until a semi open world game akin to planetside 2 is achieved). There is some diversity between the races but currently they are fairly similar, further differences are being added to the loadout system in the coming months.
Squads can have their leader set objectives using the comms rose, and tanks can be used as respawn points /offensive weapons.

Game modes include domination/ sequential capturing of points(tug of war)
Graphically the game is quite stunning, however performance is currently subpar due to being alpha and emphasis on optimisations not being the main priority yet. However I'm able to get 45fps with an i5 6600k/r9 380 4gb/8gb ram at 1080p and around 30fps at 1440p. Fps improvements are being made all the time.

Weapon choice gives a nice variety to gameplay styles from being melee focused to a braced heavy spiting suppressive rounds from a distance.

If you're considering buying this game feel free to use this referral code/link to earn yourself and I a further 4k rogue trader points to be spent on wargear .


https://www.eternalcrusade.com/account/sign-up/?ref_code=EC-19F33HLI22149

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I get the feeling that this game is too often reviewed out of context. Either it's being compared to other, complete, games or it's cast in a negative light because it hasn't yet reached all of its development goals. These would be fair criticisms if this was also being advertised as a complete game, but it is not. It's clearly Early Access. All you can do is review the content that is currently available.

Even with only two factions and three maps to play with at the moment, I'm having a hell of a good time. Battles feel hectic and dangerous, gutsy tactics often turn the tide. Be careful of friendly fire though... I may have accidentally sent a few brothers into orbit.

The classes feel decently balanced, save for the melee buffs the Ground/Traitor Assault units gain. Those could stand to be tweaked a bit.

Optimization improvements will be coming within the week for the AMD gamers out there. Personally, the game runs like a dream for me. Very smooth. (Intel i5-3570K 3.4ghz, 16GB RAM, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 670)

It gets my recommendation. The Emperor protects.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At the moment this is little more than the MP from Space Marine, but with an actual player population instead of dead servers. There are performance issues, jankiness, missing features, lag issues, and so on. So why am I still giving this a thumbs up? Because it shows promise. It's only in Alpha and yet I can sorta see the peices all falling into place. While I would strongly caution users to think if they really feel like spending money on a game that won't be finished for at least another year, I will say that I can seethis becoming the game it's meant to be eventually.

Again though, it is not there yet. At the moment there are only two factions, Chaos, and Loyalist Marines, playing in 16v16 battlefield maps. Physics is a bit wonky, and vehicles can be utterly uncooperative sometimes.

Lastly as to the obvious planetside comparison I'll just say this. Actual Multi-Crewed tanks. Driver and Gunner seperate.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am reviewing this game because I think it definitly deserves people to take a look at it. I have been burned by many early access games before but not this one. First thing to get out of the way, it is an early access game so it is unpolished, what you get right out of the gate may not be alot but bear in mind that they update quite frequently. Combat is fun, not too many good third person tactical shooters out there anymore. The game is also fairly forgiving for new players. The biggest issue I saw when reading reviews was huge lag stemming from the Unreal 4 Engine. I expected my four year old PC to just crash and burn when loading this up but all I did was turn the graphics down a bit (for me it autoset the graphics to maximum, dont know if it does that to others) and it ran perfectly. However they are working on stabilizing the game so it runs better for those who do have lag so dont fear getting this game before the price goes up.

Long story short, I highly recommend.

Death to the Corpse Emperor

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the Warhammer game I have been waiting for. It's a little like Space Marine, but you are not an unstoppable bullet sponge. Instead this game rewards uses of cover, strategy, and above all else, teamwork. Things are still a little rough as the game is in the alpha phase, but the framework underneath is pretty solid. The melee mechanics have gotten polished up more recently; as long as you don't rush into a hail of bullets and understand the rock/paper/scissors mechanic of fast swing/charged attacks/defensive bashes you can become a force to be reckoned with.

There are some issues at the moment with how teams are playing out, but this is more a problem with 40k than the game, in my opinion. With the only factions at the moment being Space Marines and Chaos Space Marines, and the game having no team switching, often the SM will outnumber CSM by a few people because of how many people love SM over Chaos, those weaklings. Recently it seems that things have started to balance out more because if one faction is flooded their time-to-find-a-game will increase while the other faction will have open spots to jump into.

The selection of weapons is pretty great at the moment as well; storm bolters, heavy bolters, and the classic bolter all play out quite differently and excell at different functions that set them apart. Your weapon loadouts also will depend upon class selection.

Scouts have a breadth of options from a stalker bolter, sniper, to the chargable plasma gun and classic infantry destroyer, storm bolter.

Heavy classes can wield the plasma cannon (which can alt-fire into an artillery death machine), a lascannon (you have to keep the laser on the target for a few moments, one-shots most classes and tears through vehicles), or the heavy bolter for amazing suppressive fire.

Raptors, jump packs of winged death, can outfit themselves with the classic chainsword (fast as hell, but less of a punch),  a powersword (medium speed, tears through armor, powerful hits but less manueverable), the poweraxe (slower, but will cut through most other melee in a clash and does great damage to vehicles), or the powerfist (slow as ♥♥♥♥, but powerful as hell; can one-shot enemies with a charged attack and fling vehicles away).

Medics can a special bolter that can do a soft-lock on enemies, powerswords, and their healing ability. Space marines heal allies  and poison enemies with a sword hit, while chaos has a healing beam.

Ground assaults are the last class and are the melee powerhouses. Space marine's assault unit carries a shield that absorbs damage at the cost of stamina and their pick of the melee weapons (chainsword, powersword, poweraxe, or powerfist). Chaos assault units are outfitted with a bolter and melee weapon with 'the mark of Nurgle' which doubles your HP.

At the moment their is your choice of Space Marines or Chaos Space Marines. The devs are planning to bring Eldar into the mix soon and Orks will follow suit soon after.

To note; the free-to-WAAAAGH idea, Orks would have a free-to-play option with limited capabilities, was actually scrapped last year.

Post-script; hitting a Predator tank with a charged fist attack and watching it fly thirty feet through the air to topple off a cliff is one of the best moments in gaming for me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yes, this game is in alpha and there are a good number of kinks to work out, but over all I am having an absolute blast with this game. It took me a little bit to find out which play style works best for me, so if you buy it and have a tough time on the battlefield, definitely spend a little time going over equipment loadouts and play around with all the different weapons and combat roles.

As a heads up on what to expect, watch out for chaos raptors and loyalist assault marines as melee focused classes can be devastating in this game and are often spammed by both sides. Also plan to make good use out of the rhino transport, as many people seem to undervalue/underuse it but it can make or break a game if used right.

If you are a fan of the 40k universe and like high intensity combat where life expectancy on the battlefield is about 90-120 seconds, then this is the game for you. I definitely recommend this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: I may be a bit partial to the game as I do love the 40k Universe as well I am not the best of reviewers (But I love this game so much).

Death and destruction are all around you, your battle brothers by your side and the weapon are the only things keeping you alive. In this game if you do not support others than you will fail. You can rush in and slay your enemies with absolute ease and do what you please, but that usefulness may not be conducive with your team’s goals. Only with teamwork and by the Emperors grace will you prevail.

I picked this game up just about a month ago and have been loving every minute of it. The plans for the future of this game are for it to be an MMO similar to that of Planetside 2 with 5 factions (Eldar, Space Marines, Chaos, Tyranids, and the Orks). Right now it is more akin to Battlefront (More so the older ones) or Battlefield. The modes are more like assaulting a “base” and capturing the points in order to increase your team’s tickets to the max before the time limit(While the enemy team tries to run down the time limit), capture points in no order, or have to sequentially capture points up until the last one.



Immersion:

Pros:
This game is the embodiment of how 40k combat should feel, you feel like a space marine with the ability to slay foes like they are pests or be the cannon fodder.

Everything in the game feels true to the 40k universe with the Exception of some names like Traitor"(Which isn't a big deal
date: but poor wording for Chaos units).\n\nCorrect weapon characteristics such as Predators don't just fire once every 10 second like in DOW(It was an ability
recommended: but yea) and make use of the autocannon as it should be and plasma is extremely dangerous to both your target and yourself as it should be
hoursPlayed:
beautifully modeled weaponry and characters.

Voice acting is very good (However I do believe they said they are going to improve it further) .

Five sub factions for each faction. Not all are implemented yet especially those factions which are not added in yet.

Cons:

Naming of certain class

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe game is good, a little messy in gameplay when it comes to large close fights, and badly optimized for performance on all settings. The graphics are good for sure, but it is really badly optimized, understandably though, as it is in Early Access.  I haven't played it very long, and probably won't until they update the optimization a little. Looking forward to more though, as the time I've had with it, I did enjoy. I wouldn't suggest this to anyone with a graphics card worse than a Nvidia Geforce 750 OC Edition (2GB), as it'd almost be unplayable on all settings.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game takes the cake with its extreme Rock, Paper, Scissors style melee system, I love the game, and even when I meet guys whose weapons beat my tactical knife, I still stagger them and pitch a melta grenade right into them and take them with me.
Sure, its got bugs, and Chaos Sorcerers have some of the strongest healing I've seen in a game supporting a full power weapon assault squadron that slaughters entire chapters of ultramarines.
Chaos is huge in power right now, and even as I lose a majority of games as an Ultramarine, I still cherish every little time I stabbed some guy to death with my butterknife against his chainsword or poweraxe because I picked up the melee system quicker than they did.
The Emperor of Mankind did not sacrifice his worldly being for us to tarnish his truth bearing lessons""

reviewText:
Early Access Review

*Constructive Comments Only*

(Will update when able)
Fun game can't wait for the PVE feature to be added. My current play time has all been in the early stages of steam release and was solo played in the PVP mode, which was the only avaliable mode at that time.

Gameplay: Fun, responsive controls and a good feel to the game that made me feel like I was actually taking part in a Warhammer 40,000 battle.

Graphics: Respectable, feels right at home for the Warhammer 40,000 style.

Audio: The amount I can recall, its been a while since I last played, was fitting to the Warhammer 40,000 games. Weapons had the proper sound. Especially the Heavy Bolter, I feel in love with that thing when I was playing.

In the end a very well rounded game at the time I played it. Will be even betetr when the PVE feature is released. All I know as of this posting is that the PVE feature will be a kind of survival mode against waves of Tyranids.

Note: Ok ignore the whine little babies expecting a complete game in Early Access. Seriously I am so tired of that kind of review. All games take some effort to play and if you can't handle that then just say so instead of whining about being slaughtered by someone better than you becuase thats called life people! Personally I get everyone has things that fit them and thing that don't in the end I am just tired of what I see as whine little baby posts.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: I may be a bit partial to the game as I do love the 40k Universe as well I am not the best of reviewers (But I love this game so much).

Death and destruction are all around you, your battle brothers by your side and the weapon are the only things keeping you alive. In this game if you do not support others than you will fail. You can rush in and slay your enemies with absolute ease and do what you please, but that usefulness may not be conducive with your team’s goals. Only with teamwork and by the Emperors grace will you prevail.

I picked this game up just about a month ago and have been loving every minute of it. The plans for the future of this game are for it to be an MMO similar to that of Planetside 2 with 5 factions (Eldar, Space Marines, Chaos, Tyranids, and the Orks). Right now it is more akin to Battlefront (More so the older ones) or Battlefield. The modes are more like assaulting a “base” and capturing the points in order to increase your team’s tickets to the max before the time limit(While the enemy team tries to run down the time limit), capture points in no order, or have to sequentially capture points up until the last one.



Immersion:

Pros:
This game is the embodiment of how 40k combat should feel, you feel like a space marine with the ability to slay foes like they are pests or be the cannon fodder.

Everything in the game feels true to the 40k universe with the Exception of some names like Traitor"(Which isn't a big deal
date: but poor wording for Chaos units).\n\nCorrect weapon characteristics such as Predators don't just fire once every 10 second like in DOW(It was an ability
recommended: but yea) and make use of the autocannon as it should be and plasma is extremely dangerous to both your target and yourself as it should be
hoursPlayed:
beautifully modeled weaponry and characters.

Voice acting is very good (However I do believe they said they are going to improve it further) .

Five sub factions for each faction. Not all are implemented yet especially those factions which are not added in yet.

Cons:

Naming of certain class
voteText: very menial con.\n\n(Gameplay as well) Grenades feel like they are thrown by a child. Space Marines should be able to at least throw it what a normal human would
helpfulPercent:
and well farther if we are talking about what is in the lore.





Gameplay:

Pros:

Combat is fun
votesHelpful: each class has a unique play style to it which makes it quite a new experience each time you choose another.\n\nLoadout locks
votesTotal: such as if you want to go Devastator with a lascannon and you choose that for your loadout you will not have access to the plasma cannon or heavy bolter for that class. This makes it so you know what type of role you want.\n\nMelee weapons are different
votesFunny: chainsword is the fastest with the least damage
commentsCount: Power Sword is slower than the chainsword and does more damage
column16: Power Axe is slower and more damaging than the Power Sword with the ability to break through a parry
column17: as for the last one I am not sure if it is a part of the NDA or not at the moment so I will refrain from mentioning it. The Apothecary also has use of his Narthecium
column18: however I have never used it for battle.\n\nTeamwork
column19: it makes all the difference in the world. One of the few strategies I like to employ is grouping up with other players who have a Stormshield and use that to protect allies behind me. Coordination is key
column20:
if the team is spread out or trying to do their own thing than loss will surely follow.

Neutral:

Vehicle handling needs improvement.

My performance is decent enough
column21: I am hitting around 45-50 fps on average since the latest update. Hardware is a GTX 970
column22: Intel I7 2600k
column23: 1TB HDD
column24: 16 GB RAM at 1600 MHz
column25:
and 1920x1080 monitor.

Certain surfaces should not allow Raptors or Assault Marines to stand on.

Some weapons need balancing.

Cons:

Stamina based melee system can be frustrating and does contain some bugs. Melee is still an enjoyable experience
column26:
but definitely needs work.

Camera needs work indoors especially for Raptors and Assault Marines. It can feel cramped in certain areas.

Raptor and Assault Marines can spam their ground pound too quickly creating a disarraying situation for all involved.

Cover mechanics are very similar to Metal Gear Solid Ground Zeroes and the Phantom Pain which is good
column27:
but they are not perfect and have difficulties with the camera sometimes.



This game is incredibly fun
column28: in its current state there is enough content to keep one playing for many hours and to me the $50 price tag has been justified EA or not(I did get it for $40 during the Founder packs though). If you have any interest in large scale battles or Warhammer 40k I would advise you to take it into consideration. What it will become down the road will be quite amazing with the hopes of competing with Planetside 2.\n\nI will update this review as more updates come out
column30: or my general opinion changes. I hope I have helped and please give constructive criticism of my review
column31: I don't do so often unless it is for certain games. Thanks"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the Warhammer shooter we've been waiting for.

Large scale battles and solid combat mechanics. Frame rates aren't great for me but it's hard to tell if it's server related or because the game is in it's infancy, I also got a fatal error after about 90mins of play (forgivable as the game is still in Alpha state).

Overall I would recommend it, though. I feel like once the frame rate and crash issues are resolved it'll be a formidable game, not to mention the addition of Eldar and Orks.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

-- THIS IS IN ALPHA STAGE --

Now that this is out the way, let's get down to buisness. The game, as in it's core combat system, is actually really good. I've been here since the very first week of alpha and i've been following it for 3 years now. I can Tell  you, the game is progressing, it is getting better each patch.

Now this might not be an MMO, This might not be planetside as of yet, Maybe all the weapons aren't here, you are right, Maybe some Races are still in production. You are right. But Now the very core of the game, the combat is more or less done and is being Tested by us.

Is it worth it ? yes

Do i trust The developpers as a customer and a person ? yes i do.

Should you try it out ? If you are a warhammer 40k fan, this game might be a dream coming true.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At the moment this is little more than the MP from Space Marine, but with an actual player population instead of dead servers. There are performance issues, jankiness, missing features, lag issues, and so on. So why am I still giving this a thumbs up? Because it shows promise. It's only in Alpha and yet I can sorta see the peices all falling into place. While I would strongly caution users to think if they really feel like spending money on a game that won't be finished for at least another year, I will say that I can seethis becoming the game it's meant to be eventually.

Again though, it is not there yet. At the moment there are only two factions, Chaos, and Loyalist Marines, playing in 16v16 battlefield maps. Physics is a bit wonky, and vehicles can be utterly uncooperative sometimes.

Lastly as to the obvious planetside comparison I'll just say this. Actual Multi-Crewed tanks. Driver and Gunner seperate.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am reviewing this game because I think it definitly deserves people to take a look at it. I have been burned by many early access games before but not this one. First thing to get out of the way, it is an early access game so it is unpolished, what you get right out of the gate may not be alot but bear in mind that they update quite frequently. Combat is fun, not too many good third person tactical shooters out there anymore. The game is also fairly forgiving for new players. The biggest issue I saw when reading reviews was huge lag stemming from the Unreal 4 Engine. I expected my four year old PC to just crash and burn when loading this up but all I did was turn the graphics down a bit (for me it autoset the graphics to maximum, dont know if it does that to others) and it ran perfectly. However they are working on stabilizing the game so it runs better for those who do have lag so dont fear getting this game before the price goes up.

Long story short, I highly recommend.

Death to the Corpse Emperor

reviewText:
Early Access Review

solid gameplay but there's a serious problem with the spacemarine faction. team play is vital in this game but they always seem to attract the worse examples. People blatantly leaving team members to die during downstate despite safe conditions.

edit - - -

Buyers beware, there is a a strong gap in the currently two avialable factions. You may want to let the excitement die down and the developers to adress many things, even for a die hard wh40k and shoot emp up fan.

Latest edit - - -

The gap has become pretty much impossible to close now, even while it is obvious players from the spacemarine side has been wising up.Chaos ground assault is chosen like a zerg class as every objective favors close range combat, which is not fun to play against and with. with the recent addition of chain axes which go through GA spacemarine shield, Chaos is 99% guarantee to win a match with rude chaos players gloating at the same time they run the same cheap GA zergs. At this time, I have changed my scoring recommondation to negative, steer clear of this game. Maybe wait for it to go into full release before purchasing, maybe once the player base starts to die, they can contemplate the massive complications that make playing this game extremely dissatisfying. One sided matches with paper mache super soldiers, this is 3rd person call of duty with flimsily designed objectives.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game with a lot of potential.

In its current state game still misses a lot of features. Development slows down each month and until next engine update stability and performance are beyond the borderline, which might be only  in late summer or so.


Game has a rather high skill floor mainly due to being so unique in terms of the mechanics. Currently its unoptimised and rough around the edges. I recommend you stay away until launch or further fixes come in.

Still a great game, with incredibly fun gameplay, if you have good enough rig and took your time to understand melee, ranged and their interaction between one another.

Old review:
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
In it's current state it misses tons of core features, that will be implemented during the year, but the game is funded, the game is constantly updated, the devs are in constant contact with player community and this is something to cherish.

Now, the game in it's current state is buggy, with some balance issues and therefore: if you want to wait fore prepared product: wait for prepared product. But if you are 40k fan, or you liked Space Marine multiplayer - you may get a lot of enjoyment even now.

But hell, it's immersive Warhammer 40k and it is awesome.
10 Defencive Bashes out of 10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

No, at least, not yet.

The game has the right formula, it is just too early to enjoy. I only have 3.6 hours in so far, but as a Space Marine and quite a few matches later, Space Marines simply lose. I don't know why exactly, but I've won probably <10% of my matches (can easy count it on one hand).

More than a few mobacancer comments... because nothing draws new players quite like the worst parts of mobas!

However, the biggest issue I have atm, is that the game is really just a melee game. I honestly don't understand why they have guns in the game atm, as sword beats gun every time. My last match, I was an apothecary (healer). Defending a point with 2 others, an enemy raptor (fast sword guy) flies in and melees one of my teammates down in one hit. Now, I've put a few rounds into him and proceed to rez the downed teammate while the other teammate is still firing into this raptor. The raptor one shots me, one shots the guy I JUST rezed, and then one shots the other teammate and proceeds to cap the point. Seriously, just  ignore guns. Want to snipe? No you don't because sword to the face, that's why! You can either 1 shot something and take almost no damage from ranged attacks, or you can BE one shot and still take the same amount of damage from ranged attacks.... That's basicly your choice right there.

The controls seem clunky. I hate the natural keybinding with a passion. It is alpha and I do think that with a little time, the controls can become a lot tighter, but right now it's kinda meh" in the control department. I feel slow and heavy mostly because I'm fighting the controls more than anything else.

Grenades

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Keep in mind that this game is in alpha state. Currently it's a lobby shooter so you get into 16 vs 16 matches where you fight over 4 points as defender/attacker. The devs state that they're making it a lobby shooter during beta so that they can refine the combat system before making it a open persistant world (I guess like Planetside 2). I personally think that this is a great idea, if the combat sucks then the shooter sucks and it's a flop.

There are some balancing issues but if you're a part of a beta, especially a alpha beta then you can expect it to have those kinds of issues. They seem to be updating the game on a weekly basis though and working on balancing which is nice.

There's reviews mentioning frame rate problems.. My friend plays on a laptop and had terrible frame rate which made me skeptical of playing, however I built my PC 3 years ago and was able to play it on max graphics with almost no clipping showing, so you can still play in 'decent' FPS but the game is far from optimized.

I really hope that they add a grouping feature to make playing with friends easier, I'd be more up to test the game if I could team up with my buddy easier than Qing at the same time and leaving a few times until we get lucky.

So far however the game seems promising, it's exciting to think about how well it could turn out being.. fingers crossed.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game wants to be amazing and it has the potential to be, just not in its current state. It's laggy, continues to stay unoptimized, and the melee system borderline ruins the entire rest of the game. Rock, paper, scissors is an overly simplistic, horrible way to do a melee system. It allows bad players to spam their mouse buttons and be rewarded for it. The animation de-syncs from what is actually happening all the time so you try to play within their horrible melee system and still get killed because of it. Game cannot ever be fun with so many issues, whether it's in Early Access" or not."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all, take note that this is in very early developement, optimization is not a top priority in this stage. (see system requirements additional notes)
lag and low frames will be an issue, but the weekly patches and hot fixes make it playable for mid range hardware.
if you are rocking a low end pc or laptop, you might want to wait.

as a huge wh40k fan this is a dream come true..a 3rd person mmo shooter but at moment the testing is limited to team deathmatch and capture the bases type deathmatches with vehicles to balance the classes.
pve content etc will come very soon which will enter also in the testing phases.

the gun play in my opinion is waaay better than THQ Space Marine.
the combat can get very intense and sometimes frustrating, but that is expected in a Alpha.
opinions differ on the melee combat, that is something you have to find out for yourself!
the developers take the suggestions and balancing feedback from the testers very seriously and more often than not those suggestions are implemented and very fast i might add.
they are very close to the community and weekly updates via Twitch, showcasing, awnsering questions and playing with the community.
i play this game literally everyday, not only because it's fun but because i want to help and report bugs so this game can be huge and speed up developement. it's a must have for any wh40k fan.

customizations are gonna be a big thing in this game so expect to see alot of content to be available to bling out on your character and vehicles in the near future.
the developers are patching constantly, with the weekly news and high activity on the forum all i can say is these people are dedicated and commited.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is far from finished, so be aware - early access is early access. Don't expect anything to be polished and bugless or you will be disappointed. If your PC is below awerage, you might have performance issues (check recommended specs!!!).

Having said that, I think Eternal Crusade is a lot of fun. There are 5 classes per faction with totally different playstyles. 2 of 5 classes are faction exclusive, so you really can feel the difference between the loyal space marines and chaos! Can't wait to see what Eldar and Orks will bring to the table... 8) As customary for 40k universe, melee combat plays a very important role. Add some psykers to the mix and you got yourself much more, than just Battlefield with 3rd person view.

The Dev team is very motivated and listens to community feedback. Check out the weekly twitch show on friday if you are interested in some developement insight and upcoming features.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Connect Four (also known as Captain's Mistress, Four Up, Plot Four, Find Four, Fourplay, Four in a Row and Four in a Line) is a two-player connection game in which the players first choose a color and then take turns dropping colored discs from the top into a seven-column, six-row vertically suspended grid. The pieces fall straight down, occupying the next available space within the column. The objective of the game is to connect four of one's own discs of the same color next to each other vertically, horizontally, or diagonally before your opponent. Connect Four is a strongly solved game. The first player can always win by playing the right moves.

The game was first sold under the famous Connect Four trademark by Milton Bradley in February 1974.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of the May 2nd Update, I have to say this game is very playable indeed in its current state. The game has gone under a lot of optimization, and runs at a solid 40-50fps on a Core 2 Duo, GTX750ti and 4gb of RAM on my end; This being at max settings at 1080p. On top of that, the game looks great, and feels like you're in the grim, dark future of the 41st millennium; With the exception of some of the maps which can be quite dull, but this game is in ALPHA. It is to be expected.
In my opinion, it reminds me a lot of Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine and Planetside 2.
By no means is this any twitch shooter, because you are shooting at nigh inhuman Space Marines adorning Power Armour, plated with adamantium - Or you will fight the Space Marines' sworn enemies, the Chaos Space Marines; Traitors that broke their oath to the Emperor during the Horus Heresy, or after. You will have to keep your aim true and steady as a Battle Brother would - because it will take many shots to down your foe, with the exception of the OP plasma weapons, which I'm sure are going to be balanced soon enough, as this game is in Alpha. Even then, being the 40k nerd I am, I don't find it frustrating, as superheated bolts of Plasma in the 40k universe will almost surely tear through anything short of a bloody Tank.
The only true gripes I have with this game are that there are no Salamanders. (Which I'm sure will be fixed later on..) and that the Graphical options have a slider instead of actual options. But again, everything is subject to change and the Devs are very good at updating the game, and will livestream every week or so to update you on new features or things that have been fixed pertaining to gameplay, performance, etc.
This makes me ever more excited for the coming introduction to the PVE elements of the game, which I'm dying to try out.
Do yourself a favour, and purchase this game and become a founder - It truly has the potential to become something great - maybe even better than Planetside 2 ever was, and with a Warhammer twist.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Does it feel like be in Warhammer 40k battle? Definitely.

Is it fun to play? Hell yeah.

Does it have bugs, missing content, lags and its non-optimized? Yep, here also.

So why do you saying yes? Because there is ton of fun in this game and if you understand that game is under development and it's still in alpha, it's in great state (trust me, I'm working in development for ten years).

So you are recommending it? Of course, if you understand what under development mean, you are fine that lot's of content will be add later, you have solid PC (you know, not optimized yet, but hey, I'm playing on notebook), and stable connection (reading some reviews it look like they are plying on WiFi, seriously, don't play on WiFi), you are good to take this funny game, where you can shoot loyalist/traitors (depends on you preference) and enjoy yourself. However if you think that this early access is to buy finished game, take it as no.

If you have something to add, you agree with me or disagree, write me a comment.

Just quick updateIf you strugle in melee same as me (you are same melee noob as me), go to controls and rebind your defensive bash" to something more intuitive. I bind it to "Q" and I have no problem with sheild bro (Melee Space Marine with shield) anymore. Just when I see he is going to attack I will look at him
date: press "Q" and then kill him with quick attack (sometimes you have to repeat it twice). So after I found out how melee actually work I have to praise it
recommended: because it's simple as it can be. Praised be Tzeench."

A MMO FPS in the Warhammer 40.000 universe? Something that every 40k fan is waiting since... ever. But should you buy it right now? Questionable.
If you're a fan, you'll probably want to support the development, so do as you wish, but if you're not, i'm sure you wouldn't mind to wait a few months. This is Early Alpha. Bugged, still early on development, really early. I'm not going to give a thumbs down cause the game is fun and will probably be a masterpiece, in the future, but right now has really little content to be released on Steam. Personally i'd have waited 6 more months of development, or at least until the orks introduction and a better overall experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all let me say...THIS IS ALPHA, THIS IS ALPHA, THIS IS ALPHA!

Now that is out of the way I'll begin.

First of all I've been a HUGE GW fan for a good three decades and have played pretty much every games based on the GW universe that's come down the pipe. EC is like if Space Marine and Battlefield had some super awesome love child. You have the third person combat style of Space Marine matched up with the large player vs player system that Battlefield is known for. You are able to play different customizable classes, take control points and use vehicles much like battlefield but coated in Warhammer 40k flavored goodness. If you are a 40k fan I would recommend buying the game now and saving some money as you'll just end up getting the itch and buying it later anyhow. IF you are NOT a 40k fan then I say either sit back and see how it develops as it is still in Alpha. Now if you are the type of person that enjoys putting in their two cents and helping a game along and are willing to part with the cash then again I suggest buying it. As I've seen so far the developers are very intune with the community and listen/read all the input that the founders have been passing their way. I do not feel this game is a money grab that soooo many that get put on steam are. I was not in favor of this early release to steam in the state of the game at this time but alsp must say I'm more than pleased with what I've seen so far and am looking forward to further development of EC and will remain a part of the Founder community.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Eternal Crusade is still in early alpha, and I'm keeping this in mind as I write this.

In short; I recommend this game. It plays much like Warhammer 40k: Space Marine, without the ridiculous grenade launcher and is hosted on dedicated servers. Once the MMO aspect launches, I have high hopes that it'll be the game that Planetside eventually stopped being.

In actual explanation:

Eternal Crusade offers gameplay for Space Marines, Chaos Warbands, Eldar and Orks. Eldar are about to be released and Orks have been mocapped and are being worked on. Units are well rounded, from Tactical, to Devastators, to Assaults, to Apothecaries and to Ground Assaults, and their chaos counterparts, the Traitor Assault getting the Mark of Nurgle instead of getting a shield, and the Apothecaries getting replaced with Sorcerers with powers both capable of healing at a distance and inflicting enemy units with the plague.

I personally like the balance of each class. Tacticals/Traitors are the most versatile with their loadouts, going from good ranged combat with the stalker bolter and the normal bolter, to good close quarter combat with the storm bolter and the melta, to good support use, such as flushing people out of cover with plasma rifles, or bombing Traitor Assaults and Ground Assaults away.

Devastators/Havocs are support based with the heavy bolter that turns everything into ribbons at point blank, and is capable of providing a suppressing effect at a distance that makes the enemy's crosshairs bloom wide open for as long as they're being shot at directly. Alongside the heavy bolter is the heavy melta, which can roast infantry in but a few seconds in close quarters and set vehicles alight, as well as the plasma cannon, which can be overcharged and shot into a heavily armored target, infantry, vehicle, or turret, and providing devastating effects. Lastly, there is the Las Cannon, which requires a few moments to lock onto a target, but does a great deal of damage to vehicles and turrets.

The most important part, is that they all carry weapons that counter vehicles, and can blanket the 'vehicle spam' problem that Planetside 2 had.

Assaults/Raptors attack from the air with a variety of melee weapons ranging from fast swinging to slow but impactful, making ample use of aerial diving their targets to discombobulate a Devastator nest, or a heavily defended point, providing surprise and shock where the Ground Assault/Traitor Assault provides only survivability while under fire of more than two to three guns at a time, and is capable of escaping after the deed is done.

Apothecaries/Sorcerers are armed a little differently, Chain Sword or Bolter for Apothecary, and Power Sword for the Sorcerer, they both are capable of inflicting and healing damage. The difference that sets them apart is that the Apothecary has to run up to the wounded to deploy a quick-reviving heal that restores them to full, while the Sorcerer can heal a target over an impressive distance over time, keeping them out of harm's way whilst doing their doctoring. Apothecaries can use their wrist device to poison the enemy, while the Sorcerer can inflict the plague on a target from a distance, capable of increasing the potency of it for each second the target is under its effect.

Ground Assaults/Traitor Assaults attack by land, as opposed to jump packs worn by Assaults/Raptors. Ground Assaults get a Shield that they can hold up to enemy fire which drains their stamina instead of their health, while Traitor Assaults are given the Mark of Nurgle, doubling their health and allowing them to carry a pistol in their off hand instead of their shield. They are 'the' vanguard of any point push, bullet sponges that last long enough for the enemy to pour in and shoot those curently set up to defend the point.

While the MMO aspect is unfinished, there are deathmatch-esque maps large enough for vehicle warfare, with varying degrees of range that play well into the different weapons, from stalker bolters, to heavy bolters, to storm bolters and so on, so forth. Little is beyond these maps besides capturing and holding objectives, but it's certainly entertaining.

Chapters, Warbands, Craft Worlds and Ork Clans can be chosen between, and upon the full game, war gear will allow you to kit and decorate your character as you see fit.

For competitive players, you may find that the TTK isn't fast enough to keep the pace that is normally eye-catching at tournaments unless you're in close quarters hip-firing a heavy bolter, a storm bolter or using a melee weapon. I personally believe that the slowed TTK provides a different type of skill, where you have to consider how best to engage your targets, and promotes the usage of headshots.

With all of the good things I have to say for the game, I unfortunately have my gripes with it. The engine is still under heavy development, and doesn't run as smooth as other polished titles. I get about 60 frames with occasional hitching whilst on a 660 TI boost, a i5 3.4 quad core, 8 gigs of memory and on windows 7, but I have to run it at its absolute lowest graphical setting, and the UI scaled down to its smallest point.

On their 'Fortress' map, I find that they have too many turrets on the defending side, capable of obliterating infantry and vehicles alike under continued firing.

Melee is clunky. Playable clunky, as power attacks overwhelm defensive bashes, defensive bashes stop fast attacks, and fast attacks interrupt the wind-up of a power attack, with easy access to breach their defenses by attacking them while their back is turned, but still clunky.

This game will be free to WAAAAGH once it comes out, where you can play the entire game for free, but only as an Ork, and you have to buy the base game to play anything else. I think it's worth the buy, if you're a fan of the WH40K setting or if you have little better to do.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is not Dark Millennium.  This will never be Dark Millennium.
Clear?  Ok, cool.
What this IS, is a fast-paced tactical shooter with integrated melee and a lovingly conveyed 40k flavor.
This is, as it says on the tin, an Alpha.  Gameplay elements, from character customization to core combat, are still being adjusted.  If you want a 40k MMO, give it a few months before you buy(posted in January of '16)- the current game build is a Space Marine-style lobby shooter with no PvE, but that is scheduled to change.  If you're hankering for some tense PvP with bolters and chainswords, however... that, it already has in spades.
Long term, will benefit from a tutorial, although some founders have assembled threads with tips for making the most of the metagame.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While still very obviously an Early Access game, there is clearly a lot of passion going into this title.

Lots of detail, true to the lore, melee combat that is actually viable in large battles (if you're good at using it), good voice acting

Looks good and runs well for an EA game, my only real issue right now is the lag, and since you currently can't choose battles based on ping it's hard to avoid.

But as a huge Warhammer fan, I will be keeping up with this game. It's already got a solid foundation built, I am very eager to see what it grows into. Seeing Orcs introduced (right now only Space Marines and Chaos Space Marines are playable factions) is going to be cool, interested in how that will work, or is there will be 3+ factions in the same battle.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

DISCLAIMER**This game is in very early alpha so don’t expect a full and complete game what your paying for right now is potential and if you’re not a fan of  Warhammer 40,000 you shouldn’t even consider the game as currently it is very bare bones**

FOR THE EMPEROR!!"
Warhammer 40k eternal crusade is an upcoming MMO with game play like that of planetside 2
date: there will be 4 factions on release which includes the space marines
hoursPlayed: the eldar and of course orks. The game will feature large environments in which these different factions will do battle upon wheither it be in the name of the emperor or simply in the name of more dakka.\n\nThat’s what this game is hoping to be but in its current state it is none of that currently there are only 2 factions which feel mostly similar (apart from a few things but more on that later) fighting in a conquest mode with 16v16. The current game is only combat and that is it no open world
voteText: story or PVE currently implemented. The pvp is quite fun even thought at the time of this review there is no progression the classes feel a bit similar but different enough not to make it an issue. There are 2 forms of infantry combat currently ranged and melee. Ranged work well enough and as you expect you point gun press the left mouse button and things tend to die. The normal bolter feels quite meaty and fun to fire which is good. The melee however currently is too strong in my opinion especially for chaos due to their traitoris assaults being able to eat a grenade to the face at full life and a lot of bolter fire. The melee is too good but this can easily be fixed with some stats and weapon balances. Now the vehicles they control like a drunk elephant
helpfulPercent: are built like paper Mache and their weapons might as well fire cold ♥♥♥♥ for all the damage they do. The game at its current state is only worthwhile if you are a Warhammer 40k fan and do not let the fact that it is an alpha is wade you from criticizing or avoiding the game I got a lot of people saying that it’s only an alpha and you shouldn’t expect it to be mazing but regardless it is still a product and costs £31.99 which is with a discount. If you are sceptical wait until the full game releases and play the free to waaagh edtion ( EDIT The free to play version may be cancelled so take this with a grain of salt and instead reaseach the game alot to see if its something you like) which gives you one character slot and lets you play as the orks. On the technacial side the game with the newest update has improved from the past but the crashing has become way more prevelant but I’m enjoying it and can give it a recommendation to people like myself who like Warhammer 40k."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game manages to be better and more fun to play that Star Wars Battle Front as early access.

The game is very early in development but is still seriously fun to play and is currently getting more attention than all the other games in my steam list. I've been an avid FPS player since the 90's but I can't think of a game that feels quite like this. The animations, weight of characters and weapon physics are spot on. The variety of weapons even in these early stages puts most games to shame.

I feel for those with optimization issues but it is running perfect on my PC. The graphics are very slick and the art style cohearant. It is very dark and gory, just the way a 40k game should be.

Worth every $$$

reviewText:
Early Access Review

How Long have I been following this game? Since 2013

How Long have I been an official moderator? Oct 16, 2013

How Much do I know about this game?  All my youtube game play and reviews of the game patches.
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLOircMrBjvxdexLlSj5-doOFOClKdOB5d.

How much info have I gathered? About 10 pages worth of updates since SEP 2013 when we could play the game.
http://forum.eternalcrusade.com/threads/upcoming-planned-changes-unofficial.47362/page-8#post-983879

Is the game fully funded? Yes. Any new players only add to the speed of content introduced. Any new players increase the possible amount of content to add.

Without making this a journal I am going to give it you quick with a block a text following

TL;DR

The game is in Alpha. It is tons of fun but it is not perfect.
Almost every week since September we have received a patch adding a new weapon, lighting, gfx....you name it
Every stated goal by Nathan has come to fruition. He has not said nor sold us on words. He has brought action to his promises.
The devs are constantly posting. They explain in detail why they made a change or the direction they are heading.
The goal of the game is recreate the feeling of being an WH40k soldier (ORK,SM,CSM,Eldar)
The scope of the game is to make a planet-wide conflict with multiple PVP objectives, PVE objectives and Campaigns. https://www.eternalcrusade.com/news/480-State-Of-The-Crusade-IV


Long Part

The game is now run by Nathan Richardsson. He has formerly worked on EVE, Dust and other LARGE, MMO type games. ALL have been successful by many metrics. Please be aware that since his addition every single goal that has been stated has been reached. (items, classes, races, factions, tyranids, maps..etc) Are the goals gigantic? Yes. It is impossible? Not with the progress we have seen. Is it fun? YES!!

By any measure so far (surveys, reviews, YouTube Videos…) the game is accomplishing its goals. With the amount of failed games given the title Early Access we gamers are already prepared for the worst. I am not saying this untrue. It is a valid concern. I want to give you a current review which I will update as needed.

1. The game is FUN!
2.  The game has 2 factions right now SM and CSM. (Ork and Eldar later)
3. The game is map based as they test out mechanics, lag, optimizations, GFX etc.
4. Every new map that has been added is bigger, taller, wider or has an interesting feature.
5. The 1st iteration of the loadout system came out Jan 21 2016. There have been dozens of additions to weapons, items combinations …ETC
To quote another member, “The developers themselves do weekly patches to address these issues, they supply us with a weekly production updates via Twitch where we can see all the new features that will be coming, and they listen to people's concerns and make sure they answer the questions people put towards them about game features and the game's future. For us who have been following this game, we know that once the game is released it will receive FREE expansions periodically (every three months) that will give players new content and abilities. The first expansion planned will add Terminators into the game!”


The game has left me only wanting for more. I will be completely convinced they have done the universe justice when they add in the Xenos Factions (properly). To me that will be the test to determine the future of this game.
I could go on and on. I have been following the game with all its ups and downs for years now. Management changes, devs leaving, doubts on the publisher and how they plan to generate income. I am normally a fickle gamer and person so anything that leaves me lacking in confidence and usually I drop the game instantly.
If you have any questions I am MOD here in steam and on the official forums
http://forum.eternalcrusade.com/members/gorilla.81/

If you think I’ve helped you decide to buy the game from my review, you can use my referral code (4000 free extra Rogue Trader points for both you and me): EC-ULA1Q6C1USBP0

ORKS FOREVER!!
WAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAgggggggggggggggggggghhhhhhhhhhhhhhh

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It is an Alpha, but I dont not think the main problem for this game is going to addressed.  It is so frustrating, not to mention sickness inducing because it is a fast paced game with a console field of view.  You swing the camera around at high speed constantly simply because you have to in order to see what is going on.  Console field of view is always terrible but this felt like one of the worst examples.

No idea if the graphics will be fixed, they are incredibly basic.  This could be addressed but given that it is clearly designed for another platform. I am skeptical. It would have a long way to go.

Outide of this, it doesnt feel like I would expect a warhammer game to feel in any way.  Spawn and spam.  Not fun. Melee is an afterthought and is a one button one move spam.   Like spamming a knife in BF4 only far uglier and because of the field of view you cant see anything besides what your looking right at.  It also never feels like it connects even when it does.

Feels like a reskin of some much old arena based shooter.

Tiny map area.

Nothing tactical about it and the marines" are dull and have no character.  The weapons feel uninspiring and like nothing ever really connects.

You cant see the server your connecting too. Its always auto at the moment so you have no idea what your ping is.  This makes for odd experiences mid game at times.

Very strongly would not recommend buying this unless it becomes something other than a terrible port of a badly designed game."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An absolutely amazing game for longtime 40k fans and a great game for new arrivals to delve into the hellstorm of the grim dark future!

The gameplay mechanics are very well done and any issues are quickly rectified by the developers without hesitation. The game is currently in alpha (aka it's a test guys, not a full game by any means), but it has still managed to represent the lore well while providing an enjoyable experience at the same time.

The amount of loadout choices given to the player is immense and there is still further customization to come. This is a game where skill and teamwork go hand in hand to allow players to choose a specialization they enjoy and to effectively coordinate with their team. Squads and communication are an important factor here.

This is truly the 40k game that fans have been waiting for!

For the Emperor!
or if you're a heretic,
Latex for the latex god! (You'll get it when you watch the streams)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far I've been enjoying a lot this game. Overall it is already a great game but the best thing is the huge potential that it has. For me what sold me the game was the fact that finally there were going to be playable Eldar in a FPS/TPS version of this universe! And I'm such a big fan of this race that I couldn't let the opportunity to support this game escape. It's true, it has been long a time without any Eldar in the game but they are certainly close to being released! And how do I know that?
Because the devs that are making this game are so awesome that they do streams every Friday, showing new content and things they have been working on.

Expect to see some bugs in the game right now, since it is in alpha stage, although in my opinion they don´t make it unplayable at all, and also it is likely that many of the Cons here are going to be fixed by the time the game launches.

Pros, Cons and my general perspective of the game:
For example the camera angle sometimes can be a bit weird when you are in cover and trying to rotate, and also the crosshair occasionally decides to not stay in the center of the screen, but that’s certainly something they are working on. And I can say that because, in one the many updates that this game has had, they fixed that issue on the vehicles crosshair, so it no longer runs away from the center when using vehicles turrets.

I agree with the fact that this game shouldn’t have a jump button, because that would lead to bunny hopping marines, which doesn´t really fit the universe, and it would break the immersion. Despite liking the no implementation of the jump mechanic, it can create some problems when facing terrain elevations (even slightly elevations). To counter this problem the developers introduced in the game some mechanics like “Vault” or “Climb” which are great but in my opinion should be expanded to more situations.

About the vehicles, I think they did a pretty good job in the design of them, they work great but there’s a situation where they can be used to spawn camp, which should be taken in count by the devs. Besides the spawn camping created with the vehicles, it isn´t that easy to spawn camp as infantry because there are multiple spawn points across the maps, so if an area is being attacked you won´t spawn right there, but around that area which is great. There are some areas where the tanks shouldn´t be allowed to go and in the maps there are some anti-tank fortications, but they can usually go over them. This is also being fixed because recently, in one of the updates they tweaked the vehicles so they won´t roll as much and are more stable. Of course it isn´t perfect yet but nothing is perfect in an alpha, and they are certainly in the right direction.

The design of the maps, the space marines and chaos models, the architecture of the buildings are all great in this game, which is also very positive when playing a fantasy universe, because it is very immersive. I’m hoping that this will also apply to the Eldar and of course the Orks and Tyranids as well, when they join in. The fact that they are working with Games Workshop is great because they make sure that everything looks and works as intended.

There are some minor balancing issues with the game now, but that’s much more subjective, because what some think is OP others think it is useless. What I mean with this is that the game will never be balanced until all the key features are in. Right now it may be balanced but every time they add something, like a new gun, a new race… it will create some balancing issues, which have to be fixed.

About the performance, yeah you need a beast to run this game properly right now. I’ll give you my example. I have a R9 390 GPU and an Intel i5-6600k processor. Now, most of the maps I play I have an average of 40-50 FPS with max settings at 1080p, but when you go to Torias, which is one of the 4 maps available right now (soon 5 with the Fortress), your FPS drop a lot (I reached a minimum of 18 FPS in that map), but this map is really big and has rain, also it isn´t very optimised, in fact the game is not optimized yet.

My only concern about the game is turning into a MMO, because right now it has battles of 16vs16 and you get this kind of performance. When they tried to add more players to the maps the FPS dropped quite a bit. This is also the first time I’m actually playing an Alpha of what’s going to be a MMO, so it may be normal I don´t know. Soon with the introduction of the new Fortress map, we will be able to tell if it gets worse since it’s going to be 30vs30 battles in this map.

To conclude this review, I totally recommend this game mainly for 40k fans, even if you can´t run the game right now, you will possibly be able to run it later when it is optimized, so you might as well buy right now and get the benefits. For people who are not sure if they like the direction that the game is taking, I recommend waiting to see how it goes, because according to the developers the game is funded anyway. It is after all a game in alpha stage, so there’s still so much to come, and the idea behind it is awesome. The developers are also very open to the community and they are absolutely listening to us, in order to make this game the best Warhammer 40k out there.

If you liked my review and considered it helpful, make sure to use my code when creating an account for the game.
Referral Code: EC-FH537JT08M8VJ With this code you get free 4000 RTP (credits to spend in the future store).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do not bother, and wait for the full release to see if this development team can actually deliver or not. The game is good/ok (depending on your standards) to look at, it's very poorly optimized and the gameplay is pretty bad, if you're expecting thq's space marine level of quality when it comes to combat you'll be disappointed. The dev's team enthusiasm is commendable, but enthusiasm alone doesn't make great games, and this for now is far from great. As i said, wait for release and see if they can deliver because they talk and promise a lot, but so far i have zero faith in the project.

I had 150 or so euros invested in this with a founder pack, but asked for a refund sometime in 2015 and it honestly felt like one of the best decisions of the year. My advice, play Planetside 2 if you want this game type while you wait for this, don't give them any money for now.

Don't get fooled by the large amount of positive reviews, the vast majority of people in alpha and early access are 40k fanboys with little to no previous gaming experience, and trying to have discussions with them on the testers forums is like talking to brick walls because literally everything for them is great as long as it has a 40k skin on it and they can't be objective about the game itself.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hey guys,
I've honestly never written a review before, but I wanted to let you know the truth about this game.  And for the record,  I understand that it is early access, and I love warhammer, played for years, huge fan of the lore, and always looking forward to any game that comes out for it.  That being said, this game is exactly what I was hoping for, great models, great feel, but in it's current iteration, this game is the most unbalanced piece of s%#! I have ever played in my life.  If you have a jet pack and a melee weapon, you win.  End of story.  Bolters and heavy bolters, a staple of the Warhammer world, are absolutely worthless.  There is no point even trying to shoot someone, they simply roll at you, melee you, you die.  Respawn, melee'd, dead.  Rinse and repeat.  Hopefully this game will get better in the future, but for right now, DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Played this game for only a few hours, and I can only recommend this game to those who loved Space Marine and are willing to settle for a game that barely has anything. So let's see: Horrible optimization, the framerate never goes over 30, there are freezes happening all over the place, especially when you're fighting with melee weapons. And melee combat is kinda skinny. It's glitchy, got stuck in my oponent once, also got stuck when rolling away etc. etc. Few maps, few modes in general, this game is a real Early Access, I'd say it should cost around 25 euros at its current state. No keybindings yet (coming via next patch I've heard), you can only set the screen resolution and there's no customization. Well, sure, you can create your own build for a class or whatever you wanna call it and choose between four different weapons per class and so on.

I certainly believe you gotta be a Warhammer fan like me to enjoy this game. And yes, I like this game, but I couldn't recommend it to anyone just yet.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Melee is completely unbalanced and primitive to use. Melee classes are dominating battlefield and all they have to do is spam light attack to win. All it takes to kill you with melee is 3-4 light strikes with Chainsword (takes not even 2 seconds), meanwhile you have to empty half of your magazine into them to kill them. Also, melee system works on rock-paper-scissors system, so all you have to do against non-melee class is spam and after cca. 4 hits you will brake their defence and spam them to death. Same can be used against melee classes, but not so efficiently. And did I mention that there is auto aim? Yes, there is auto aim for melee and pistol, so all what melee class has to do, is to look at you, hold aim button and spam and wherever you go, he will automaticaly turn. And if you manage to get out of his reach, he can finish you with auto aim pistol.

So, to wrap this up. Melee is king, if you are non-melee class and you meet melee class and no one helps you, you are dead.
They don't have to turn with you, because they have auto aim, all your evasive actions are useless.
They don't have to use any strategy in melee, all they have to do is spam light attack and roll around to avoid attacks.

All of thic could be easily fixed and this would be awesome game, but because devs are lazy to implement working and balanced melee system, game is almost unplayable, when you get squad of melee noobs against you. If you don't mind being recked by every spammer you come across go ahead and buy the game, you might have fun. But if you want balanced game, where one class isn't dominating other, this game is not for you.
