Early Access Review

Absalutely Great game.  keep in mind it is in alpha, but it is worth the buy.  the developers are great at listening to the community and really have the players in mind.

As for the game.  I have been playing not long since the game has been in closed alpha, and in that time i can truly say it jsut keeps getting better and better.  Every time they come up with a system that i think it really good, it changes, and while usually that would annoy me that is not the case with this game because they never senselessly change things, they IMPROVE them.  I do not play on this game all the time as for the moment it is very limited on game modes (ALPHA)  but i can truly say that whether it be me getting killed or killing people on the game, I always have fun playing it.

If you are a WH40K fan or even if you just liked playing space marine i highly recomend you getting this game, it is completely worth it and you will not regret buying into the most unique and best made wh40k games to ever come out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even with my old laptop I was able to play well enough to see it's potential for great fun! It's in early access so don't be a goober and post hate when it's not even done yet. I wouldn't recommend getting it if you have an old computer like mine because developers have to optimize stuff at the end of making games.

The best part it is the developers themselves, if you need any help deciding these reviews are good but watching their twitches and how much they cared for and developed the game over the years is the best way to know for sure!! ♥

As far as the gameplay I've experienced it has suppression, a melee combat system, the jump jet pack things, vehicles, power fisting (and all the inappropiate jokes =p), healing, controlling points, customization, executions, chainsaw swords, Loyalist and Chaos Marines, and very good ingame graphics.

What's to come is Eldar (clearly superior, /hairflip), Orks (comical space barbarians), other factions via expansions, open world, loot, fighting tyrannids (the space locusts) and maybe more for pve and loads of maps.

I'm most excited for the potential for a left for dead style of X faction vs tyrannids and the Devs hinted the tyrannids may be playable in this mode.

Also my referral code is EC-Z4PVOTHOSOUB5 if you want free stuff via the store. Please use our referral codes because it helps us both out =D I'm fairly sure it's still usable with early access.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a simple question, Do I recommend this game? Yes and No. But read closely as to why:

First, this game is Early Alpha at best, with limited weapon and tank choices, only 2 factions (excluding 'sub-factions' which at this time are very minor cosmetic changes), small and limited maps and many bugs from crashing (I have not experienced this) to missing textures (literally missing grates inside of pipes, I even have a screenshot), this game is obviously only barely at the point of being playable and has not laid out any more than the bare basics of a game it wants to be. As is, this game is a solid 5/10 for gameplay but not worth 40$ (maybe 15 as is).

However! It must be said, if promises are to be believed, and gameplay stays roughly as it is now (promised to be much more fleshed out and balanced in the future) with much bigger battles, better customization, larger maps and way more everything (Orks, Eldar, actual differences in sub-factions whether they be mostly cosmetic or not) with smoother gunplay and melee combat this came could be the real Warhammer deal! Well worth the money now with the promise of a grand future!

BUT!! I for one have NEVER believed the promises of others and solely look upon their actions, beyond the promises and roadways they chart. And so far... I see a warhammer game I could be proud of *FUTURE TENSE*. Being a huge fan of Warhammer 40k (and many things similar to it, and it to) I feel this game is worth the price of admission as of right now due to what they could put out in the future. As well, I actually like the feel of the gameplay as it is now and feel it can be improved upon. This developer hasn't dug themselves a hole to crawl in to, they actually seem to care (excluding GW's um... Reputation).

If you want a game right now to play, this is a 16v16 player battlefield-like (many people killing over few objectives, all capture based) mixed with Gears of War 1 control-style (cover, rolling, heavy feel of foot and gun) and Warhammer 40k textured game will not be worth the 40$ to anyone but a solid fan of Third-Person Shooter with Massive Multiplayer.
And for a solid Warhammer 40k piece in the future? Yep, it is worth the 40$ IF IT DELIVERS.

It's a possibility that this game could tank straight out of the gate, or steam on it's tracks to deliver a great experience. Only time will tell, and I for one DO recommend for anyone that like Warhammer 40k Shooters.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So this is going to be a somewhat lengthy but hopefully informitive review, and since it appears the the devs are thankfully quite open to critique and improvement this game has a lot of potential, quite a lot in my opinion, however the long and short of it is, right now, do not buy this game as it stands it's awful. This review will be updated as development progresses.

I hate to mention bugs because it is in an alpha state and you are effectively paying for the privilege of being a bugtester, but buyer beware, it is -very- alpha right now. I will not complain about the lack of optimization either, but be aware I run a Titan X, with an Overclocked I7 4790k, with 32 GB of DDR4 Ram and I still get chugs in my framerate from time to time.

What I wish to dedicate the bulk of this review to is the generous amount of baffling and simply god-awful design decisions that have gone into this game, but before I get into that let's take a minute and talk about the positives.

Art/Audio - The emperor would be very pleased with the art direction of the game, the marines look excellent. Without a doubt someone involved in the hobby did the design work on the art of both the characters and the world, and you cerainly feel like you're stepping into the grim darkness of the 41st millenium. Bolters sound like bolters, evergy weapons sound like energy weapons and the rumble of a tanks engine approaching is unmistakeable. The voices are basic, but the lines are thematic, and delivered well, if a little repetitive. The devs need to either add a lot (and I mean a whole lot) of new lines or have the character not deliver 1 of the same 3 speeches every time they spawn. In addition, chosing a space marine and chaos space marine chapter who both wear red was possibly the worst art decision ever made in a game, the two are virtually impossible to tell apart in a firefight or melee, especially with multiple characters on screen at once, however this is more of an interface peoblem, as unless you keep your finger glued to the q" key
date: the game gives you no indication of who is on who's side.\n\nKudos to the artists and art direction aside

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After having played this game for a couple of months, I'd have to say this is one of the more enjoyable pre-release, alpha games I've yet played. It does have it's kinks, but that's natural for an early access game. I'm a huge fan of the 40k universe and I feel like this game does a very good job of representing that universe. While I see alot of people complain about melee combat being broken, I find that once you get it figured out, it's one of the best melee systems I've seen. It's just not very well explained and can be frusterating to a new player. But the basics are everyone has three melee attacks. quick attack, strong attack, and defensive attack. They kinda have a rock, paper, scissors effect. You just have to mess with it. Ranged combat works extremely well with little more than the typical issues that plague third person shooters, such and objects getting in the way of your line of fire, but they've fixed all the glitches that let you shoot through stuff.  I'd like to list a few pros and cons that I feel are present in the game at it's current state.

Pros
-Amazing 40k world including referances and quotes from codexes and 40k lore
-Great gameplay with a healthy mix of melee combat and intense shootouts
-Executions (nuf said)
-Various classes and loudouts that will continue to improve throughout development

Cons
-It's early access so it's incomplete and several balance issues are the result of them testing and trying various things to find that balance.
-Minor bugs and glitches can be annoying. While I personally haven't run into anything game breaking, it's sometimes annoying when you try to crouch behind cover and your character just stands there getting shot in the face. (This has improved greatly since eraly access launch tho)
-No PvE content as of yet, but PvE content is planned.
-Not much in the way of tutorials so some things require some patience and a little trial and error to figure out. You can also ask other players, most are willing to help.

Overall I say it's easily worth the $40 price tag for the 40k fan. The Devs have been great and I can't wait to see where this game goes from here. I feel like it has incredible potential and has held my attention like very few multiplayer games have. I'm extremely excited about the progressions trees being added in the near future because that will only add more appeal to the game. If your the kind of person who doesn't have patience for games to change nd grow, then I can't recommend this game for you. But if you like third person vs multiplayer, the 40k universe or action games with a progression system then this game is great. Thanks for your time and I hope this helps.

Early Access Review

Eternal crusade is a fraction of the game I was expecting when I bought a founders pack years ago . The open world 40k mmoshooter (ala planetside 2) never came to fruition .

What you will get is a clunky 3rd person shooter , with limited and terribly designed maps , Vehicle play on shoebox maps ( why bother) ,horrible camera angles , ♥♥♥♥ poor physics and repetative gameplay . The 4 races at the games inception are still a way off, leaving players fighting marines vs marines with horns and very little else to differentiate the 2 current races .

Behaviours progress is snail paced with there weekly updates a total waste of time , consisting of maybe peek at a minor upcoming change and half a hour of the same clowns playing the same 4 maps over and over ... seriously it would be more entertaining and less painfull to take up cutting yourself for entertainment .

Not to mention at £32, basicly the price of fully realised AAA title this game is a total rip off  . Save your money and don't pay to Alpha test this crap .

Leave your 'muh 40k feelz' at the door. The amount of fanboys giving this game is a thumbs up is ridiculous. So what do you get for $40? ♥♥♥♥ poor optimization (AMD machines get really ♥♥♥♥ed here), incredibly basic combat system and shallow customization.

Will it get better? Probably, but at it's present state it's not worth your money.

Early Access Review

Hi All,

Well for a game in early Alpha this feels very Solid, it still has some performance issues but it is better than most.

Pros

- large battles with 40K stuff.
- Gun play is pretty good when you get use to it.
- you get to play some of your favourite 40k factions, with more to come.
- informative DEVS.
- Weekly updates.
- large squad sizes.
- Execution Finishers for extra points =).
- Friendly fire is on, so watch those melter cannon shots.
- Large scale maps with forts and NPC guns Turrets.
- One squad can change a whole game by being coordinated.

Cons

- Some performance issues ATM lag spikes.
- I am still learning so I get owned alot ;)

In conclusion I Believe that this game is worth purchasing for the forty dollar price tag.

Thanks For Reading
Greavus

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm enjoying the game, and at the same time, I am not. There are quite a few issues with the game, issues that I believe will never really be sorted. Imagine Warhammer 40k: Space Marine, take all the movement, tactics, weapons, stats and all. Make it all worse, add latency (both internet and framerates), throw in a couple of extra players. Now you have Eternal Crusade.

No matter how hard they try, they will never duplicate Space Marine, that game (the gameplay and PvP combat) was near flawless, as good as it gets. The only real slayer of Space Marine was no dedicated servers, which later on with player decline became more apparent. But it seems that the genre in combination with Warhammer was not as popular as could have been. Had nothing to do with the actual game, but peoples' taste in games and art style.

This project is doomed to fail, it already has to some degree, it will NEVER get a big player base. And thus, for legal matters as well as reputation, all they can do is push for a release with a decent enough game before dropping all the support for it and moving on to the next project.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The 40k franchise was on a streak for a while there, unfortunately that streak has come to a halt. Huge, longtime fanatic of the lore, the hobby, many of the games, been waiting for over a year for this game to get to early access. Complete disappointment. Still, my go-to action 3rd-person 40k shooter will remain 40k: Space Marine. If you're a fan of W40k:SM, prepare to be wildly discouraged and disappointed. This neither adopts nor makes any attempt at emulating the fluid gameplay of SM, and replaces it with clunky, slow-moving inaction, mixed with map designs that are boring and/or completely off the mark for a decent multiplayer map. Graphics are equally non-immersive. Drab textures, uninteresting character upgrades, and zero incentive to work as a squad or unit.

I had so much hope for this game. Huge let-down.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really want to like this game since I love the universe, but their direction right now is troubling.  It has all the things that make a game horrible:

1 hit kills
100 to 0 Stun locks
So many particle effects you can't see
Invisible tank rounds with auto aim
rock-paper-scissors melee that if you lose once you're stun locked until dead
Jump packs! except if they land near you you get stunned and 1 shot

I am not talking about balance, which is bad, but it is alpha.  These are core game mechanics that they need to change.  Nobody likes to be out of control of their character while they watch themselves die or killed in one hit.  Just terrible design decisions in this stage.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game in a nutshell:

THE GOOD-

Great Graphics
Great Audio, voice overs and sound track

THE BAD-

Does not feel like the Warhammer 40K Universe.
Everyone dies like flies.
Spawn, kill 2 enemies in 5 seconds, then get killed in 2 seconds, respawn, rinse repeat.
Not epic at all, just another shooter, and a bad one at that.
Game mechanics change drastically with each patch and update for the worst.
Small Maps.
Limited to 32-64 players.
Cheats, exploits galore.
One shot kills galore.
Only 50%  true to Warhammer 40K lore
Cannot play with friends or guildies, no grouips, warbands or party.
Long que's even when hardly anyone is playing.
Not fun.

THE UGLY-

To give you an idea of how bad this game is, one of my steak friends who I have known a long time is a Warhammer 40K fanatic, and spent a ton of money on this games Founders Access". Then the Devs changed the game from a "deep and immersive MMORPG" to just another shooter and a bad one at that. Despite the hundreds of dollars he spent on Founders acces he refuses to play this game now or even read abotu it.

All the good stuff such as large and.or open world

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is stil VERY early access and suffers from a lot of issues. One such: Logging in can be a pain if you have a firewall or an anti virus scanner.

As for the gameplay, It's tf2 meets battlefield and it does neither well. Balance issues plague the game as someone dives into your team, kills 7 of you with a melee weapon and flies off. The entire time you'll be shooting them of course but they continue to slaughter.

The weapons feel very weak and the netcode suffers from latency issues. Even with a 100mb/10mb connection, I still had horrible issues with hitting.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I obviously missed something here. I was expecting an MMORPG. Instead, I got a boring version of Planetside 2 with some Games Workshop 40K paint slapped on it. Classes have no real diversity, everything is light and fast and nothing feels meaty or powerful. Meh.

As usual, the Techmarines are overlooked entirely and there are no Iron Hands faction. I know the rest of the Emperium sees the doctrine of the Omnissiah as heresy, but come on - can't we get a little love?

I have a dream of recreating my Deathwatch character in an MMO - a Techmarine that slowly replaces all of his flesh with robot parts and becomes an indestrucible walking, sentient tank of destruction just a rung or two under the revered Dreadnoughts. Seems like I'll never get to do that, since every 40K game that comes out ends up being an unintelligent, straightforward shooter.

Early Access Review

Here is a review that actually applies to this game: Developers are out of touch with what people want. I bought this for myself and a friend to play Space Wolves, Orks and Eldar.

Instead of getting this in quickly, they have the generic marines and generic chaos marines. Okay, that's fine. But instead of working on many of the races people want they work on guns and maps.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If I had to summarize this game right now in one sentence: It feels like APB Reloaded.

Why did I rate UP? Honestly, to give the dev team a chance, I think they've gotten dealt the short straw with a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ budget.

Devs need to work very hard on this game. Dont spend your money just yet!

One of the things that is the biggest letdown is the glass cannon feeling. Right now the two factions in the game are Space Marines and Chaos Space Marines. Running and moving about feels weighty but once you get into a fight you are basically just a glass cannon that dies extremely quickly. In my opinion, increasing the time it takes to kill someone by just a little bit might remedy alot of this.

Right now the game just needs more;

More polishing, more weapons, more vehicles, more maps, more good stuff!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Greetings Brothers (Aliens, Mutants and Hertics)

In the grim future there is only war and what a war it is. Yes, there are still some bugs to iron out but as it stands this game is fantastic especially if you squad up. The maps are well worked out, except Harkus those Quad cannos really do bring about the black RAGE sometimes.

This game has endless possibilities as well as the multiplayer there will be a PVE, where you and four frinds take on swarms of Tryanids. The ingame store is another great addition where you can buy upgrades and other goodies that will enhance your gaming experiecne. The fully customised armour schemes will really give every player the chance to make their character truly their own.

I love this game and as a massive Warhammer fan, growing up as a kid, I am super excited to be finally able to play a game that brings this universe to life.

Long live the Emperor

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early access. The very term conjures up immages of unfinished, glitchy, horrible games. Most Early access games never get finished, and just take players' money and run. That is not the whole story here. Warhammer 40,000: Eternal Crusade is is possibly your best bet as far as early access game go. While the game is very unfinished, it's not bad as far as games go.

For one thing, the devs are some of the pest I've seen on steam, as far as PR goes. They have a weekly live stream (which you can watch on youtube and twitch), and they listen to the fans. And they're not too proud to admit when they made a mistake. That alone is enough for me to want to support them.

As for the game itself, it's very limmited right now. It's meant to be an mmotpsrpg (massivly multiplayer online third person shooter role playing game) not unlike Planetside 2, except in the Warhammer 40K universe, and with pve (player versus environment) aspects. In its current state, however, it is mostly just a lobby shooter. That's not a bad thing, however, I'm more than eager to get to the good stuff.

Which brings me to the game's flaws. Melee is currently broken, and the latest patch that was supposed to fix it (amung other things) caused crash after crash after crash etc. (I'll get to melee combat later). Being in early access, most of the game isn't there. So options are extreamly limmited. Also, (though I don't believe the devs are at fault for this) Chaos Space Marines beat Space Marines 9 out of 10 times. So, if you want to win, join the forces of chaos. Though this could change at any time. Also, there's no tutorial. So you need to figure things out on your own, or look on youtube for tutorial videos.

Melee is definatly a plus in this game (dispite its broken state). It's gasically a rock paper scisors game. fast attacks beat charges attacks, defensive bashes beat fast attacks, and strong attacks beat defensive bashes. This makes the melee combat more dynamic. There is no better satisfaction in this game than executing an enemy that you spent a good minute or more dueling. These duels are what I live for. And, of you get it down, you can beat anyone in melee dispite your class. (As a Devistator [heavy ranged class] I beat an assualt marine [jetpack melee class] in a melee duel, and excecuted him for his trouble). This will only get better once Eldar and Orks are added.

Finally, this game will feature Orks, Eldar, Space Marines, And Chaos Space Marines once the game reaches beta, and finally launch. Not to mention the devs plans to later add Tao and other races. The future of this game looks good, and I am happy to recomend this game. It's not much now, but it'll be fully worth it once it's finished. But if you want to wait untill it's actually worth the 40 bucks you'll put into it, I can't blame you.
